author: Amy Daire
title: Books to read in your 20s
text:
Start making a list. Marco Nürnberger/Flickr
There is always something to learn from books, whether it's a compilation of poetry, a memoir, or a piece of classic literature. The best reads broaden your horizons, give you a new perspective, or offer valuable advice to you as a reader, which is especially great for people who have their whole lives ahead of them.
Whether you've just turned 20 and want to up your reading game or are on the verge of 30, any of these choices would be a perfect addition to your reading list.
Here are 21 books to read in your 20s.
View As: One Page Slides "Beloved" by Toni Morrison Amazon This book was named " the single best work of American fiction published in the last twenty-five years" by The New York Times for a reason.
The haunting story about life post-slavery is studied wide and far in high schools across the country, but going back to it in your twenties (or reading it then for the first time) will make you look deeper at your own past, present, and future.
Buy it here » "52 Cups of Coffee: Inspiring and insightful stories for navigating life's uncertainties" by Megan Gebhart Amazon Instead of diving head-first into the typical 9-5 job after she graduated, Gebhart decided to use an experiment as a means of finding her passion. She sat down for coffee with a new person once a week for an entire year to learn about the careers and lives of different people, including the co-founder of Apple and a former VP at Starbucks.
Buy it here » "The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao" by Junot Díaz Amazon This book might just cure you of pessimism. The author takes readers on an emotional roller coaster with this Pulitzer Prize winning novel. It will probably make most readers cry, but it will definitely make every reader a little bit braver.
Buy it here » "Giovanni’s Room" by James Baldwin Amazon This highly-acclaimed novel follows an American man as he's living in Paris, and became a staple in literature for finally shedding real light on both homosexuality and bisexuality.
It will make you want to travel to France, but more importantly, it will give you a deeper understanding of how fear and shame can affect a person.
Buy it here » "The Fall" by Albert Camus Amazon If you decide to open this book, there's a good chance that you'll end up with a blurry, skewed vision about the basic foundation of life. It will lead you to question your own morals, your views on what's right and what's wrong, and everything you think you know about good vs. evil.
Buy it here » "Leaves of Grass" by Walt Whitman Aamzon It opens with the poet's long yet insightful "Song of Myself," that tedious poem you may have studied in school. Re-reading it in your 20s will make you think about your own many multitudes and facets.
Buy it here » "The Secret History" by Donna Tartt Penguin This book is a perfect read for your college years. It's full of Greek mythology and amazing Quote: s, but is best read when campus life and those close friendships of college are still somewhat fresh in your mind.
Buy it here » "Tuesdays with Morrie: An Old Man, a Young Man, and Life's Greatest Lesson" by Mitch Albom Amazon Albom met with his dying college professor, Morrie Schwartz, every Tuesday for months to discuss life's biggest lessons. He shares their interesting class-like discussions in the book and has already imparted Schwatrz's lasting wisdom on more than 12 million readers.
Buy it here » "The Subtle Art of Not Giving a F---" by Mark Manson Amazon After decades of being told that positivity is the key to happiness, Manson told the world the opposite.
This raw "self-help" book will make you realize that there are only so many f---- to give, so picking which ones are actually worth giving will make you happier and healthier. It's both realistic and grounding.
Buy it here » "White Teeth" by Zadie Smith Amazon Smith's debut novel, which she wrote when she was only 24 (!), caught the world by storm. It tackled everything from sex to parenthood and religion to gender politics as it follows the lives of two World War II veterans as they immigrate in London.
Buy it here » "The Year of Magical Thinking" by Joan Didion Amazon This memoir might just teach you everything you need to know about loss and making sense of things that are seemingly senseless.
Some say that it's a book best read once your married and have children, but there's a lot to be said for preparing yourself for the reality of those often-romanticized moments in life.
Buy it here » "On The Road" by Jack Kerouac Amazon Kerouac's road trip narrative is a coming of age classic. Many ideas in the novel (freedom, dissatisfaction, and longing) are most prevalent in your 20s as you come to terms with the reality of true adulthood.
Beware of the apple pie cravings that come with it.
Buy it here » "Modern Romance: An Investigation" by Aziz Ansari Amazon The comedian takes an in-depth look at why dating and love today isn't anything like the way your parents have likely described it to you. His hot take is surprisingly informative and scientific as well as universal, especially in the digital era.
Buy it here » "The Marriage Plot" by Jeffrey Eugenides Amazon Similar to Ansari's "Modern Romance," this novel questions many old-timey thoughts on love, marriage, and romance.
It follows a college senior in the 1980s as she studies Jane Austen and George Eliot, as well as their "marriage plots" and how love really works in the new era.
Buy it here » "Year of Yes: How to Dance It Out, Stand In the Sun and Be Your Own Person" by Shonda Rhimes Amazon Rhimes has built an empire with her Thursday night primetime TV hits, but this encouraging book is as great as her shows. She was a classic introvert until she decided to turn things around by dedicating an entire year to saying "yes."
If it doesn't motivate you to live a little more, nothing will.
Buy it here » "Blackout: Remembering the Things I Drank to Forget" by Sarah Hepola Amazon Yes, your twenties are supposed to be fun and wild, but as Hepola will tell you in this memoir, working hard and playing harder isn't always as great as it sounds.
The 30-something now-sober writer looks back on her years of binge drinking in a way that is hilarious, insightful, and helpful.
Buy it here » "The Alchemist" by Paulo Coelho Amazon This book is all about listening to your gut and following your heart. With lessons like chasing your dreams and never giving up, there's a lot for twenty-somethings to learn over and over again.
Buy it here » "The Dirt" by Mötley Crüe and Neil Strauss Amazon This book will make you realize that your own crazy twenties were nothing . It's full of adventures, confessions, affairs, drugs, and of course, rock and roll.
It houses the autobiographies and stories of the band's four members, Tommy Lee, Nikki Sixx, Vince Neil, and Mick Mars, and thanks to it's outrageous tell-alls, it is a page turner from beginning to end.
Buy it here » "How Should a Person Be?: A Novel from Life" by Sheila Heti Amazon This novel does take a stab at answering the question "What kind of person should you be?" as well as tackling life's smaller questions like "How should a person love?"
It's centered around Sheila herself, making it part-autobiographical, and has a lot a 20-something can appreciate, whether it's an obsession with having artistic friends or being vulgar in the name of honesty.
Buy it here » "Fangirl" by Rainbow Rowell Amazon This new adult novel follows twins Cath and Wren who have been devoted "Simon Snow" fans their entire lives. As they grow older Cath can't seem to let go of writing fan fiction, but Wren is trying to move past it.
The coming of age story is loosely based on the "Harry Potter" fandom, but anyone who's ever felt even the slightest bit "nerdy" for loving something unique will relate.
Buy it here » "Yes Please" by Amy Poehler Amazon Her hilarious collection of poems, lists, essays, mantras, advice, and photographs is inspirational and thought-provoking. She delivers each story with the same amount of funny as she does on screen all while giving you an endless supply of words to live by.
